turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Immunotransplant.
turn.2: The total cohort of T cells in an organism maintain homeostasis – a consistent total number of T cells in the peripheral blood.
turn.3: how does the body do this?
turn.4: Transient elevations in peripheral blood T cell counts cause the whole population to diminish, transient depletions cause the whole population to proliferate, generally maintaining a roughly total T cell count.
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.6: The latter situation –lymphodepletion– has been studied extensively and the proliferation of mature T cells upon transfer into the lymphopenic host is referred to as “lymphodepletion-induced” or “homeostatic” proliferation.
turn.7: what is the significance of this?
turn.8: It has been shown that homeostatic proliferation induces not only quantitative changes in T cell cohorts, but qualitative changes as well, such as increased function and the development of a memory-cell phenotype.
turn.9: what is the cause of this?
turn.10: The mechanism of these changes has been shown to be primarily due to upregulation of a group of cytokines including IL-7 and IL-15 induced by lymphodepletion.
turn.11: is there any other interesting information?
turn.12: Additionally, lymphodepletion is a non-selective method of eliminating several known regulatory, or immunosuppressive, subsets of immune cells, such as regulatory T cells.
